user_query: Why doesn't change in accounts receivable on balance sheet match cash flow statement?
text-davinci-002_response: The reason that the change in accounts receivable on the balance sheet does not match the cash flow statement is because the cash flow statement uses the indirect method of accounting for cash flow from operations. This means that they start with net income at the top, and then adjust it with line items for the various non-cash activities that contributed to net income. The key phrase is that these are accounting for the non-cash activities that contribute to net income. If the accounts receivable amount changes from something other than operating activity (e.g., if they have to write off some receivables because they won't be paid), the change didn't contribute to net income in the first place, so doesn't need to be reconciled on the cash flow statement.

user_query: How does a lender compute equity requirement for PMI?
text-davinci-002_response:
Here's how the payment works: The bank collects 1/2% of the loan value from you at origination.  So, for a typical $100K mortgage, you would pay $500 for PMI up front.  The bank remits this to the PMI company.  Then, each year, you pay an additional .5% of the loan balance to the bank, who in turn remits that to the insurance company. So, for that same $100K mortgage, you would pay $500 the first year, $495 the second year, and so on, until you pay off the mortgage, sell the house, or reach a point where the value of your house has increase enough that you can refinance at an 80% loan to value, and drop the PMI. PMI protects the bank from loss in the event of foreclosure.

user_query: How long should I keep my tax documents, and why?
text-davinci-002_response:
As a general rule of thumb, most experts recommend that you keep tax-related documents for at least three years. This gives you plenty of time to file an amended return, if needed, and protects you in case the IRS audits your return and asks to see your records. 
There are, however, some instances in which you may need to keep your records for longer than three years. For example, if you own a business or rental property, you should keep your records until the statute of limitations expires for that year's return. The statute of limitations is the period of time the IRS has to audits a return and assess additional taxes. For business returns, the statute of limitations is three years. For most individual tax returns, it's three years as well, but there are a few exceptions. For example, if you file a return claiming a loss from worthless securities or a bad debt deduction, the statute of limitations doesn't begin until the security or debt becomes worthless. 
In addition, there are certain types of records you should keep indefinitely, such as records relating to real estate or stock transactions. These records can be used to determine your basis in the property, which is used to calculate your gain or loss when you sell the property. You should also keep records that document major life changes, such as birth certificates and marriage licenses, as well as records relating to any changes in your business, such as the incorporation of your company. 
The bottom line is that you should keep your tax records as long as they're relevant to your current financial situation. Once a return is no longer relevant, you can probably shred it. But it's always better to err on the side of caution, so if you're unsure whether or not to keep a particular document, go ahead and hang on to it for a few more years, just to be safe.

These codes are used when transferring money between banks, particularly for international wire transfers, and also for the exchange of other messages between banks.

First, you need to understand how credit card companies calculate interest. Typically, they use the daily average balance method. Under this method, they take the beginning balance each day, add any new charges, and subtract any payments or credits. They then calculate the daily periodic rate by dividing the annual percentage rate (APR) by 365, and multiply that by the average daily balance. Finally, they multiply the daily periodic rate by the number of days in the billing cycle, which is usually about 30. 
So, if your APR is 15% and your average daily balance is $1,000, your daily periodic rate would be 0.04109% (15% divided by 365), and the interest charge for the month would be $16.87 ((0.0004109% times 1,000) times 30).

user_query: What is a straddle?
text-davinci-002_response: A straddle is an options strategy in which one buys or sells options of the same maturity (expiry date) that allow the buyer or seller to profit based on how much the price of the underlying security moves, regardless of the direction of price movement. IE: A long straddle would be: You buy a call and a put at the same strike price and the same expiration date. Your profit would be if the underlying asset (the stock) moves far enough down or up (higher then the premiums you paid for the put + call options) (In case, one waits till expiry) Profit = Expiry Level - Strike Price - (Premium Paid for Bought Options) Straddle.

user_query: Can I fully deduct capital losses against discounted capital gains?
text-davinci-002_response:
Capital gains and losses.  In general, capital gains and losses are separated into two categories:   Long-term capital gains and losses.  You have a long-term capital gain or loss if you held the capital asset for more than one year before you disposed of it. For most assets, the one-year holding period begins on the date on which you acquired the asset. The date you acquired the asset is the trade date. It's the date you and the seller closed the deal and you took possession of the asset.   Short-term capital gains and losses.  You have a short-term capital gain or loss if you held the capital asset for one year or less before you disposed of it. If you disposed of an asset before the holding period was up, figure your gain or loss as if you had held the asset a full year. Document-1: No, capital losses can't be used to offset gains from the sale of assets at a discount. Making a profit by investing in mutual funds, real estate, stocks or other assets at a reduced rate and then selling them at a higher market rate is called flipping. And it's perfectly legal to do. However, you can't deduct capital losses from your discount flipping profits. 
Can I fully deduct capital losses against discounted capital gains?
No, you can't fully deduct capital losses against discounted capital gains.

user_query: What will happen when a bid price is higher than an ask price?
text-davinci-002_response:
Document-1: On most exchanges, if you place an order to buy or sell a stock at a price that is immediately achievable with someone else's order, then the trade happens right away. That's called an "at market" order. If, on the other hand, you place an order at a price that's different from the price that's currently being bid (in the case of a buy order) or asked (in the case of a sell order), that order is considered a "limit" order. It may not trade right away because there's no market maker or other trader currently willing to buy or sell the stock at that price, but the order will stay in the system until it can be matched with an opposing order.
When you place a limit order, you're specifying the maximum price you're willing to pay to buy a stock (or the minimum price you're willing to accept to sell it). So, if you place a buy limit order for a stock at $20 and the ask price subsequently rises to $30, your order won't be executed until the price falls back to $20 or lower. Similarly, if you place a sell limit order for a stock at $30 and the bid price subsequently falls to $20, your order won't be executed until the price rises back to $30 or higher.

user_query: Why sometimes payable date is BEFORE the ex-dividend date?
text-davinci-002_response:
Dividends are typically paid out on a company's stock on a quarterly basis, but the specific date of payment varies depending on the company. Some companies actually do pay their dividends on the ex-dividend date, but others have a date that is a few days or even a week before the ex-dividend date. The payable date is typically set by the company's board of directors.
There are a few reasons why a company might choose to set the payable date before the ex-dividend date. One reason is that the company wants to make sure that shareholders who are entitled to the dividend actually receive the payment. By setting the payable date a few days or even a week before the ex-dividend date, the company can be sure that the shareholders will get the payment even if there is a delay in processing the dividend.
Another reason why a company might choose to set the payable date before the ex-dividend date is to give shareholders more time to reinvest their dividends. If the payable date is set too close to the ex-dividend date, shareholders might not have enough time to reinvest their dividends before the share price goes down. By setting the payable date a few days or even a week before the ex-dividend date, shareholders have more time to reinvest their dividends and potentially make more money.
